ofx:section.ofx:title: Operating System (Debian Linux)
ofx:section.ofx:paragraph: Debian is an operating system composed of free software mostly carrying the GNU General Public License. The operating system is developed by an Internet collaboration of volunteers aligned with The Debian Project.

Debian GNU/Linux is one of the most popular Linux distributions for personal computers and network servers. Debian is seen as a stable Linux distribution, and as a consequence has been used as a base for other Linux distributions, there are over 140 active Debian derivatives, one of the most popular ones is Ubuntu.

Since Debian can be used free of charge, it can easily be obtained from the projects website. There is a huge variety of installation methods to choose from. A very convenient one is using the minimum installation CD. You can download the disk image for your architecture (mostly i386 for older 32-bit machines and amd64 for newer 64-bit CPUs like Intel Core processors and above) from http://www.debian.org/distrib/netinst. Then the image needs to be written to a CD or DVD recordable. The Ubuntu project offers HowTos for all common operating systems like Microsoft Windows, Apple Mac OS X and Linux on how to actually burn this image to the disk at https://help.ubuntu.com/community/BurningIsoHowto. Once the CD or DVD is prepared, the computer needs to be booted from the optical disk drive and the (non-graphical) installer should be selected from the boot screen. The Debian installer then guides you through the complete setup process.

ofx:section.ofx:title: Package Manager
ofx:section.ofx:paragraph: Debian comes with a package manager called apt-get that can be used to download and install software automatically. The package manager will be used to install several additional packages.

ofx:section.ofx:title: Sudo
ofx:section.ofx:paragraph: sudo is a program for Unix-like computer operating systems that allows users to run programs with the security privileges of another user (normally the superuser, or root). Its name is a concatenation of "su" (substitute user) and "do", or take action.

Unlike the su command, users typically supply their own password to sudo rather than the root password. After authentication, and if the /usr/local/etc/sudoers (sometimes found at /etc/sudoers) configuration file permits the user access, then the system will invoke the requested command. The sudoers configuration file enables a huge amount of configurability, including but not limited to: enabling root commands only from the invoking terminal; not requiring a password for certain commands; requiring a password per user or group; requiring re-entry of a password every time or never requiring a password at all for a particular command line. It can also be configured to permit passing arguments or multiple commands, and even supports commands with regular expressions.
